posts.name: Dainen griffes
posts.cooked:
Hey everyone,

I’ve seen a few threads on wire management, but I wanted to post this to gather ideas on some more specific things all in one place.

-How do you manage large runs with many wires? They always seem to become unruly and hard to organize.

-Should we run wires directly through parts of our frame, or should we run them over?

-For CAN wires, what is the best type of connector to use? We always have problems with CAN wires disconnecting, which ends up costing us valuable time.

-Is there an updated diagram for REV components? The current diagram we have doesnt have quite a few of the new components they’ve added.

-New radio advice. I’ve heard horror stories about the new radio and I want to clarify some things before we end up ruining our only radio

Those are all the questions I can think of right now, I look forward to your responses!

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
“Horror Stories” is a bit of an exaggeration. Learning curve simply because its different than what we have used for a decade?? Sure.

I’ve been keeping a close eye on the new radio threads here on CD and to my recollection there have been perhaps 3-4 teams/radios that have NEEDED professional technical support from WCP /VIVID-HOSTING although I do not have official data on that.

I have seen 0 RMA’s needed/posted about on CD ? Maybe 1 early on but my memory is fuzzy?

And of the 3-4 above I recall 2 because of user misconfiguration/interrupting the firmware update process - which is something you don’t want to do while updating any devices firmware, like your router…that’s a good way to brick it. And these radios were still recoverable with Vivid-Hosting support.

To give you some guidance and not CD thread history recollection though: If you are intimidated by the new radio docs from Vivid-Hosting the manufacturer or WPILib , then get your feet wet using the configuration utility recently released that should simplify the process.

Id recommend reading up on the VIVID-HOSTING and WPI docs regardless, like reading all the instructions on a test section to be sure you understand what’s going on and what you should expect to happen before diving into it. That will prevent you from landing in many pitfalls like selecting the wrong firmware to update too or not understanding the blinking lights pre, during, or post firmware upgrade.

posts.name: Dainen griffes
posts.cooked: The thing’s ive heard have been horror stories lol, from what I was told from another team is that if you mess up while updating the new radio it would just get bricked. They made it sound like it wasn’t hard to do…

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
It sounds like that other team didn’t read the docs and know what to expect and what to do when!

I’d encourage you to dive in, do the pre-work, and try for yourself/form your own opinion.

I had a fairly easy time updating and configuring 7 radios. I had more trouble with the roboRIO configuration causing me problems than the radio!

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Cable chain is the go-to for -moving- wire runs.

Running inside tubes is good for protection but terrible for fixing.  YMMV.

Our go-to for CAN is those dual channel lever nuts.  Clear for the inspection win!  I kinda hate Duponts.  Even locking ones.  We, um, might have had a kid wire an entire robot with locking Duponts and neglect to strip the end of the wires.  Had to cut the whole mess back off.  Scream.  The only thing worse to crimp than Duponts is JST connectors.  OMG!

Even more awesome for CAN is to do star topology for your swerve corners with these suckers:

Name: mini transparent 2 in 6 out wire connector Size: length 1.29 inches x width 1.24 inches x height 0.53 inches Rated voltage: 250V Rated current: 32A Spring: stainless steel Package: 10 pieces Material: shell flame retardant and high temperature...

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: iirc new radios should be imaged with the post-brick (1.2.5+) firmware straight from VividHosting, so that should solve a lot of the problems

posts.name: BrianAtlanta
posts.cooked:
I want to share a couple of videos discussing this topic.

PCH Pit - GA/SC youtube show about teams in our states. We did a live stream with @BordomBeThyName from 1678 called “How to keep your robot moving”

Enjoy the videos and music you love, upload original content, and share it all with friends, family, and the world on YouTube.

Team 2910 - Jack in the Bot have a GREAT 2.5hr video that you should watch ALLL of it.  But the last chapter (1hr) covers electrical tips and tricks to keep your robot moving.

posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked:
Dainen:

-For CAN wires, what is the best type of connector to use? We always have problems with CAN wires disconnecting, which ends up costing us valuable time.

The connectors can’t fail if there are no connectors at all! A good solder joint is always going to be more reliable than any connector. Most of the time, try to solder unless you know you actually need to have a connector for some specific reason (i.e. to swap out an entire mechanism with a pre- wired spare mechanism). Same goes for power wires.

Fewer connectors = fewer failure points.

posts.name: Eric Tate
posts.cooked: I would say yes BUT the ability to swap out components between matches with out breaking out the soldering iron needs to be considered.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
A soldered connection is still a connection.

The quality of the connection is more dependent on the quality of the execution than the connection technology.

Teams need to design around their capabilities.

There are teams where they claim to have members who can solder well enough to use it as their preferred way of joining wires. It is nice that your team is one of those.

I have worked with teams that had a few team members who quickly learned to solder well. Then those team members graduated. I have also worked with teams where none of the team members could learn to solder well.

Over the last several decades designing electronic/electrical equipment for industrial applications, I have dealt with about as many instances of bad solder joints as bad crimps/connectors.

posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked:
philso:

A soldered connection is still a connection.

Sure. Soldering gives you a single solid, permanent bond between the wires. Whereas connectors allow easy disconnection by design, and each individual connector can have several connections per wire - all of which are additional potential failure points.

I’ve seen dozens of examples of connectors coming apart during matches, or even connectors that are mostly connected but lose contact intermittently - these can be tough issues to find. I think I have only seen 1 solder joint fail, and it was in a place that had been soldered multiple times where a wire was tightly bent around a sharp corner, so it was bound to break at some point.

philso:

I have worked with teams that had a few team members who quickly learned to solder well. Then those team members graduated. I have also worked with teams where none of the team members could learn to solder well.

Soldering is certainly a skill that takes practice. Just like using a dremel or a drill, most people aren’t great at it on their first try, but with practice it becomes very easy. If you train new members to solder each year, you’ll always have people who are able to solder. Same goes for crimping and using connectors properly - connectors also need careful attention.

MrT8:

I would say yes BUT the ability to swap out components between matches with out breaking out the soldering iron needs to be considered.

I agree

kingbrandon14:

(i.e. to swap out an entire mechanism with a pre- wired spare mechanism)

But the majority of mechanisms/components never end up needing replacement during an event. Adding connectors to every motor or CANcoder just in case is usually just adding unnecessary points of failure into the system.

And if it comes down to it, soldering a couple wires only takes a couple extra minutes in the pit, it’s not impossible to do between matches by any means.

posts.name: Eric Tate
posts.cooked: Not impossible but still takes longer. If I relate it to industrial equipment, you don’t see much solder connection of motors and controllers in the field. Definitely each to their own in terms of preference but “the majority of components not needing replacement” does not matter when one does need replacing in a hurry. Again just my opinion - there is no absolute right or wrong here.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
kingbrandon14:

Soldering gives you a single solid, permanent bond between the wires

This is only true when the soldering is done properly. A solder joint is still a connection that has a chance of failure.

kingbrandon14:

Soldering is certainly a skill that takes practice. Just like using a dremel or a drill, most people aren’t great at it on their first try, but with practice it becomes very easy. If you train new members to solder each year, you’ll always have people who are able to solder. Same goes for crimping and using connectors properly - connectors also need careful attention.

Soldering is a manual skill. Practice does improve one’s skill level. That practice takes a lot of time. There is a significant difference between being able to solder and being able to solder well. A poorly done solder joint will still fail. It is nice that you have been lucky enough to have batches of students who can do soldering to the standards you are happy with. I have only found a few, which is not a sustainable situation. I have worked with other electrical engineers who, after 10-15 years, still are terrible at soldering, often because they have a low level of fine motor control, and ask others to do the soldering for them.

kingbrandon14:

I’ve seen dozens of examples of connectors coming apart during matches, or even connectors that are mostly connected but lose contact intermittently - these can be tough issues to find.

There are connectors that don’t come apart under the conditions found in an FRC robot. There are ways to secure the wires so that stresses are not applied to the connector or solder joint.

In many instances, the joint between two wires in an FRC robot will be difficult to reach position. Reaching such positions with a soldering iron becomes problematic and can cause damage to other nearby components. A connector can be disconnected and reconnected much faster and easier.
